questions.text: An elderly male patient was brought by his son because he was not using his left arm for day-to-day functioning. He has an unkempt appearance on the left side of his body and has a history of bumping into door frames while walking through them. The evaluation performed is shown below. Where does the lesion in the brain cause this presentation? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right parietal

 

The patient’s symptoms suggest left-sided hemineglect, characterized by a lack of awareness of the left side of the body and environment. This is typically caused by a lesion in the non-dominant parietal lobe, which, for most people, is the right parietal lobe. The clock drawing test, where the patient clusters numbers on one side, further supports this diagnosis of hemineglect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right parietotemporal: This could affect spatial awareness but is more specific to complex visual and spatial processing issues.

 

Option B. Left parietal: Lesions here would affect the right side of the body and typically do not cause hemineglect.

 

Option D. Right premotor cortex: Would affect motor planning but not typically cause hemineglect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Left-sided hemineglect is typically caused by a lesion in the right parietal lobe.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a history of bilateral lower limb weakness which progressed to his upper limbs in a year. On examination, he had weakness in both lower limbs and wasting in the left upper limb. Babinski sign was positive and the deep tendon reflexes were absent. He has no sensory loss or any autonomic dysfunction. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ALS


Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by mixed upper and lower motor neuron signs. The presence of both Babinski sign (an upper motor neuron sign) and absent deep tendon reflexes (a lower motor neuron sign), along with the chronic progression and lack of sensory/autonomic involvement, strongly points towards ALS.

 

Other Options:


Option A. MS: Multiple sclerosis typically involves sensory symptoms and demyelinating plaques visible on MRI, which are not described here.

 

Option C. GBS: Guillain-Barré Syndrome is an acute condition with a rapid onset and is primarily a lower motor neuron disease without upper motor neuron signs like the Babinski reflex.

 

Option D. Tropical spastic paraparesis: This condition is associated with HTLV-1 infection and presents predominantly with upper motor neuron signs, not the mixed signs seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ALS presents with both upper and lower motor neuron signs, progressive weakness, and no sensory or autonomic dysfunction.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with bilateral pitting pedal edema, and abdominal distension. On examination, he had ascites and auscultation revealed an S3. Which of the following defects can be seen in this patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tricuspid regurgitation

 

The patient's presentation of bilateral pitting pedal edema, abdominal distension, ascites, and an S3 heart sound is indicative of right heart failure. Tricuspid regurgitation leads to right heart failure because it causes blood to back up into the right atrium and subsequently into the systemic venous circulation, resulting in the observed symptoms. Chronic smoking may contribute to pulmonary hypertension, which can exacerbate right heart failure and tricuspid regurgitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic regurgitation: Typically causes left heart failure with symptoms like dyspnea and pulmonary congestion, not right heart failure.

 

Option C. Aortic stenosis: Leads to left ventricular hypertrophy and heart failure, primarily affecting the left side of the heart.

 

Option D. Mitral regurgitation: Primarily affects the left side of the heart and results in pulmonary symptoms and left heart failure rather than right heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tricuspid regurgitation is a common cause of right heart failure, presenting with symptoms such as pedal edema, abdominal distension, and ascites.

questions.text: A man with diabetes was on medication and forgot to take his meals before going to the gym. During his workout, he collapsed, and his blood sugar level was found to be 50 mg/dL. Which of the following oral antidiabetic drugs can result in hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glimepiride

 

Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea, a class of drugs that stimulate the pancreas to release more insulin. This increased insulin release can lower blood glucose levels significantly, leading to hypoglycemia, especially if meals are skipped or physical activity is increased. Sulfonylureas are well known for their potential to cause hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metformin: This drug primarily decreases hepatic glucose production and increases insulin sensitivity. It rarely causes hypoglycemia when used alone because it does not directly stimulate insulin release.

 

Option C. Acarbose:  An alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that slows carbohydrate absorption in the intestine. It does not cause hypoglycemia when used alone, as it does not affect insulin secretion.

 

Option D. Dapagliflozin:  A sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor that promotes glucose excretion in the urine. It has a low risk of causing hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy because it does not increase insulin levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Group of drugs that tend to produce hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy:

 

  • Insulin
  • Secretagogues: Sulfonylureas, such as glimepiride, can cause hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy due to their mechanism of increasing insulin release from the pancreas.

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol 3 days ago, presented with irritability, altered sensorium, and visual hallucinations. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Delirium Tremens

 

Delirium Tremens (DT) is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that typically occurs 48-72 hours after the last drink. It is characterized by:

 

  • Autonomic instability (e.g., tachycardia, hypertension, hyperthermia)
  • Severe agitation and irritability
  • Altered sensorium (e.g., confusion, delirium)
  • Visual and auditory hallucinations

 

DT is a medical emergency with high morbidity and mortality if not treated promptly.

 

The treatment of choice is benzodiazepines, which help to control agitation and prevent complications such as seizures. Long-acting benzodiazepines like diazepam are preferred unless there is liver dysfunction, in which case shorter-acting agents like lorazepam or oxazepam are used.

 

Special Considerations for Liver Impairment:

 

  • Cirrhosis or Severe Liver Failure: In patients with compromised liver function, the metabolism of drugs, particularly those processed by the liver, can be significantly impaired.
  • Short-Acting Drugs: Lorazepam is recommended as it is less reliant on hepatic oxidation and more on glucuronidation, which is relatively preserved in liver disease.
  • Oxazepam is also suggested as it undergoes direct conjugation in the liver without the need for extensive metabolism, making it safer for patients with severe liver impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke’s Encephalopathy: Wernicke’s Encephalopathy is caused by thiamine deficiency and presents with a triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and confusion. It does not typically present with hallucinations or irritability.

 

Option C. Korsakoff Psychosis: Korsakoff Psychosis is a chronic condition resulting from untreated Wernicke’s Encephalopathy, characterized by severe memory impairment/ amnesia and confabulation. It does not present acutely and lacks the autonomic instability seen in DT.

 

Option D. Alcohol Withdrawal Seizures: Alcohol withdrawal seizures typically occur within 6-48 hours after the last drink and present as generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS). They do not present with the prolonged altered sensorium or hallucinations characteristic of DT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium Tremens is a severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome occurring 48-72 hours after cessation of alcohol intake, characterized by autonomic instability, severe agitation, altered sensorium, and hallucinations. It requires immediate treatment with benzodiazepines to manage symptoms and prevent complications.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of HTN, DM2, and DLP is brought to the ER because of reports of palpitations and dizziness. ECG is ordered and shown in the image. His temperature is 36.8°C, PR is 106/min, RR is 18/min, BP is 84/46 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. What is the next step? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. DC shock

 

The patient presents with symptoms of palpitations and dizziness and is found to have an irregularly irregular rhythm on ECG, consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF). The absence of distinct P waves and the presence of fibrillatory waves further support this diagnosis.

 

The patient's vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 84/46 mm Hg, indicating hemodynamic instability. In cases of tachyarrhythmias such as AF, the management approach depends on the patient's hemodynamic status. For patients who are hemodynamically unstable, immediate intervention is required.

 

Synchronized DC cardioversion is the treatment of choice in hemodynamically unstable patients with AF. This procedure involves delivering a synchronized shock to restore normal rhythm. The shock is timed (synchronized) to occur at the peak of the R wave to avoid inducing ventricular fibrillation.

 

Specific contraindications for using synchronized direct current (DC) cardioversion (synchronized DC shocking) are sinus tachycardia, multifocal atrial tachycardia digoxin toxicity. But in cases where a patient is unstable and experiencing shock, immediate cardioversion is necessary despite these contraindications, underscoring the urgency in treating life-threatening arrhythmias in acute settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant used to prevent thromboembolic events in patients with AF. However, it is not the immediate intervention of choice for hemodynamically unstable patients. The priority in such cases is to stabilize the patient's condition, which requires electrical cardioversion.

 

Option B. Beta blocker: Beta blockers are used to control the heart rate in AF. They are not appropriate for initial management in an unstable patient, as they do not address the immediate need to restore a stable rhythm.

 

Option C. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic that can be used in the management of AF. However, it is typically used in stable patients or after electrical cardioversion has been attempted. In an unstable patient, immediate electrical cardioversion is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hemodynamically unstable patients with atrial fibrillation, immediate synchronized DC cardioversion is the next step to restore a stable rhythm and improve hemodynamic status.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents with altered sensorium, breathlessness, hypotension, and bradycardia. Examination revealed non-pitting edema of the extremities. She has a long-standing history of weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance, and menorrhagia. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myxedema coma

 

The patient presents with several symptoms indicative of severe hypothyroidism. These include altered sensorium, breathlessness, hypotension, bradycardia, non-pitting edema, weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance, and menorrhagia. In hypothyroid patients, a severe, life-threatening condition called myxedema coma can develop. This is characterized by a profound deficiency of thyroid hormones, leading to critical manifestations such as altered mental status, hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, and edema.

 

Myxedema coma requires immediate medical intervention. The treatment of choice involves intravenous administration of thyroxine (IV T4) and IV hydrocortisone. IV hydrocortisone is essential because many patients with myxedema coma have subtle adrenal insufficiency, which can become overt with the initiation of thyroid hormone replacement. This combination helps stabilize the patient's condition and addresses both thyroid and potential adrenal insufficiencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septic shock: While this condition involves hypotension and altered sensorium, it is usually associated with signs of infection, fever, and a source of sepsis, which are not described in this patient's presentation.

 

Option B. Cardiogenic shock: This condition involves heart failure and typically presents with signs of fluid overload, severe breathlessness, and possibly chest pain, none of which are noted in this patient’s history.

 

Option D. Hyperthyroidism: The symptoms of hyperthyroidism include weight loss, heat intolerance, tachycardia, and increased bowel movements, which are opposite to the symptoms exhibited by this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myxedema coma is a severe, life-threatening condition of profound hypothyroidism, characterized by symptoms such as altered sensorium, bradycardia, hypotension, and non-pitting edema. Immediate treatment involves IV thyroxine and IV hydrocortisone to manage both thyroid and potential adrenal insufficiency

questions.text: A tall 10-year-old boy presents with Sexual Maturity Rating 5 and hyperpigmentation. His BP is 150/100 mm Hg. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency

 

The presentation of a tall 10-year-old boy with a Sexual Maturity Rating (SMR) of 5 and hypertension (BP 150/100 mm Hg) indicates precocious puberty. The SMR of 5 typically signifies full sexual maturity, which is unusual for a 10-year-old and suggests precocious puberty.

 

Hyperpigmentation is likely due to elevated ACTH levels, which can occur in congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). The key to the diagnosis is understanding the enzyme deficiencies that lead to CAH and their associated symptoms.

 

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency leads to increased production of 11-deoxycorticosterone, a mineralocorticoid that causes hypertension due to salt retention. This condition also results in excess androgen production, leading to precocious puberty in boys and virilization in girls.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 21β-Hydroxylase deficiency: This is the most common cause of CAH but is typically associated with salt-wasting, not hypertension. It results in increased androgen production leading to virilization and ambiguous genitalia in females, and precocious puberty in males.

 

Option C. 17β-Hydroxylase deficiency: This deficiency is characterized by hypertension and hypokalemia but does not usually cause hyperpigmentation or precocious puberty. It often results in underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Option D. SCC (side-chain cleavage) deficiency: This enzyme deficiency leads to a severe form of CAH with salt-wasting and adrenal insufficiency but is not typically associated with hypertension or hyperpigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency in congenital adrenal hyperplasia causes hypertension due to salt retention and precocious puberty due to excess androgen production.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with the following lesions that started 2 days after he developed a fever. On examination, there are generalized vesicular eruptions over the trunk. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chickenpox

 

Explanation:

 

The description and image provided indicate a diagnosis of chickenpox (varicella). Key features include:

 

  • Generalized vesicular eruptions over the trunk.
  • The lesions appear as "dew drops on a rose petal," which is characteristic of chickenpox.
  • Chickenpox lesions are typically in various stages of development (macules, papules, vesicles, and crusts) at the same time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Smallpox: Presents with a more uniform appearance of lesions and typically starts on the face and extremities.

 

Option C. Monkeypox: Presents with fever, lymphadenopathy, and a rash that is similar to smallpox but usually more severe.

 

Option D. Shingles: Generally presents in a dermatomal distribution and occurs in older individuals or those with a history of varicella.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chickenpox is characterized by generalized vesicular eruptions that look like "dew drops on a rose petal" and appear in various stages simultaneously.

questions.text: All of the following are the core clinical features for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Orthostatic hypotension.

 

Lewy body dementia (LBD), also known as dementia with Lewy bodies, is characterized by specific core clinical features. Orthostatic hypotension, while commonly observed in LBD due to autonomic dysfunction, is not classified as a core clinical feature but rather as a supportive feature for diagnosis.

 

Central feature: Dementia (Essential for the diagnosis of DLB).

 

Core Clinical criteria include the following:

 

  1. Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.
  2. Recurrent visual hallucinations that are typically well formed and detailed.
  3. Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder (RBD).
  4. Spontaneous cardinal features of parkinsonism.

 

Supportive Features of LBD:

 

  • Autonomic Dysfunction: Including orthostatic hypotension.
  • Severe Sensitivity to Antipsychotic Drugs: Patients may experience severe motor and neuroleptic sensitivity.
  • Other Hallucinations and Neurological Signs: Can include auditory hallucinations or transient, unexplained loss of consciousness.

 

Onset of dementia preceding or within 1 year of onset of parkinsonism differentiates Lewy Body dementia from Parkinson's disease with dementia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluctuating cognition: Fluctuating cognition is one of the hallmark symptoms of LBD, characterized by significant variations in attention and alertness. This fluctuation is more pronounced than what is typically seen in other forms of dementia, such as Alzheimer's disease, and can vary from hour to hour or day to day.

 

Option B. REM sleep behavior disorder: REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) is a core feature of LBD, where patients physically act out their dreams, often vividly. This disorder is a result of the loss of normal muscle atonia that should occur during REM sleep, leading to potentially violent movements and vocalizations during sleep.

 

Option C. Recurrent visual hallucinations: Visual hallucinations in LBD are typically well-formed and detailed, often involving people or animals. These hallucinations are a core feature and differ from the more nebulous or less structured hallucinations seen in other disorders. They are thought to be due to the underlying Lewy body pathology affecting cortical brain areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orthostatic hypotension is a supportive, not core, criterion for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia.

 

Reference - Harrison 21e/Neurology, DLB Chapter 434 /12305.

questions.text: Low renin hypertension is seen in all of the following, except:(NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Renovascular hypertension

 

Explanation:

 

Renovascular Hypertension is associated with high renin levels (high renin hypertension). This condition involves renal artery stenosis leading to decreased renal blood flow, which stimulates the juxtaglomerular cells to release renin. Increased renin levels then lead to elevated angiotensin II, causing vasoconstriction and increased aldosterone, which results in hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Essential hypertension: Low renin levels and normal aldosterone levels.

 

Option B. Conn’s syndrome: Low renin levels and high aldosterone levels.

 

Option D. Liddle’s syndrome: Low renin levels and low aldosterone levels due to constitutive activation of the epithelial sodium channel.

 

Hypertension Comparison Table

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renovascular hypertension is characterized by high renin and high aldosterone levels, while essential hypertension, Conn’s syndrome, and Liddle’s syndrome are associated with low renin hypertension.

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady presented to the casualty with Hb - 5.4 g/dL, urea-86 mg/dL, creatinine- 6 mg/dL, calcium - 12 mg/dL, potassium - 4.4 mEq/L. Bone marrow aspiration shows > 60% of plasma cells. What is the next line of management? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone + Fluids

 

Features are suggestive of Multiple myeloma presenting with Mild Hypercalcemia with no pulmonary edema. Hence, treatment with steroids and IV fluids are recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dialysis is recommended if Hyperkalemia, Pulmonary edema, refractory acidosis, and Uremia.

 

Option C. Dexamethasone + lenalidomide is recommended in definitive therapy for MM along with bortezomib +/- Daratumumab (Anti CD38).

 

Option D. Bone marrow transplant is considered upfront in high-risk disease as definitive therapy.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Immediate management of a newly diagnosed multiple myeloma patient presenting with anemia, renal failure, and hypercalcemia should prioritize rapid medical intervention to stabilize the patient. This includes hydration and the use of steroids to reduce plasma cell proliferation and calcium levels. Subsequent treatments will be based on the patient’s response and overall treatment strategy.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Plasma cell dyscrasia/Chap 111

questions.text: A 60-year-old female, on treatment for diabetes for the last 10 years, has experienced three episodes of candidal vulvovaginitis in the last two months. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Canagliflozin

 

Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor, a class of drugs used to treat type 2 diabetes. One of the well-known side effects of SGLT2 inhibitors is an increased risk of fungal infections, particularly candidal infections of the genital tract. This is because SGLT2 inhibitors increase the amount of glucose excreted in the urine, creating an environment conducive to fungal growth. Therefore, in patients with a history of recurrent candidal infections, such as the 60-year-old female in this case, SGLT2 inhibitors like canagliflozin should be avoided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin: The most common side effect of metformin is gastrointestinal upset, particularly diarrhea. It does not increase the risk of fungal infections.

 

Option C. Glipizide: This sulfonylurea drug primarily causes hypoglycemia as a side effect. It does not have a significant association with increased risk of fungal infections.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone: This drug can cause weight gain due to fluid retention but does not increase the risk of fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a history of recurrent candidal infections, SGLT2 inhibitors, such as canagliflozin, should be avoided due to their association with increased risk of genital fungal infections.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, having lost her newborn, is producing breast milk, which risks developing into a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. Which drug can prevent this complication? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cabergoline

 

In this scenario, the primary goal is to suppress lactation to prevent milk stasis and subsequent breast abscess formation. Lactation is driven by the hormone prolactin, which is released from the anterior pituitary gland. To suppress milk production, prolactin release must be inhibited.

 

Cabergoline is a dopamine receptor agonist that works by stimulating dopamine receptors, which in turn inhibits prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary gland. By reducing prolactin levels, cabergoline effectively suppresses lactation, thereby reducing the risk of milk stasis and breast abscess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone: This drug is a progesterone receptor antagonist primarily used for medical termination of pregnancy. It does not have a role in suppressing lactation.

 

Option C. Chlorpromazine: This is an antipsychotic medication that blocks dopamine D2 receptors. Blocking dopamine receptors would actually increase prolactin levels and promote milk production, thus potentially worsening the risk of milk stasis and abscess.

 

Option D. Metoclopramide: This drug is a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist and is sometimes used as a galactagogue (to promote milk production). Like chlorpromazine, it would increase prolactin levels and thus is not suitable for preventing lactation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cabergoline, a dopamine receptor agonist, is used to suppress lactation by inhibiting prolactin secretion, thereby preventing complications like milk stasis and breast abscess.

questions.text: Calculate the GCS Score in an intubated patient, with findings of eye movements to pain and abnormal flexion? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) E2VNTM3.

 

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is used to assess the level of consciousness in patients with traumatic brain injury and other conditions. In this scenario, the patient is intubated, which affects the ability to assess the verbal response. The current nomenclature for denoting non-testability due to intubation is "NT" (Non-testable) for the verbal component.

 

  • Eye Opening (E): The patient opens eyes in response to painful stimuli, which scores 2.
  • Verbal Response (V): The verbal component is non-testable (NT) due to intubation.
  • Motor Response (M): The patient exhibits abnormal flexion (decorticate response), which scores 3.

 

This combination gives a GCS score of E2VNTM3.

 

 

NT = non-testability of the corresponding component.

 

Used mainly in acute TBI (Traumatic brain injury).

 

Update:

 

1. GCS-P Score takes pupillary activity into consideration.

 

P = Pupillary non-reactivity

 

2 = Both pupil

 

1 = One pupil

 

0 = None

 

Minimum = 1, Max = 15.

 

2. FOUR score (Full outline of unresponsiveness) is currently employed having better sensitivity, specificity and PPV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In intubated patients, the GCS verbal score is marked as "NT" for non-testable. The GCS remains a vital tool in assessing the level of consciousness, particularly in emergency and critical care settings, ensuring that changes in the patient’s neurological status are promptly recognized and appropriately managed.

 

Reference - Harrison/Neurology/Basics /Chapter 443-TBI

questions.text: A 20-year-old male came to the emergency after sustaining an injury and was given 0.25% bupivacaine for regional anesthesia. A few minutes later, he became unresponsive and pulseless. What would be the ideal management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CPR & 20% IV Intralipid

 

The scenario describes a case of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), which can occur after the administration of local anesthetics like bupivacaine. LAST can cause severe cardiovascular and central nervous system toxicity, leading to symptoms such as seizures, coma, and cardiovascular collapse, as seen in this patient.

 

The management of LAST involves:

 

  1. Immediate initiation of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) if the patient is unresponsive and pulseless.
  2. Administration of 20% intravenous lipid emulsion (Intralipid). This treatment, known as lipid rescue or lipid emulsion therapy, acts by creating a "lipid sink" that absorbs the local anesthetic from the tissues and blood, reducing its toxic effects on the heart and brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CPR & Calcium gluconate: Calcium gluconate is not the primary treatment for local anesthetic toxicity. It is used in cases of hyperkalemia or calcium channel blocker overdose.

 

Option C. CPR & Start Dobutamine infusion: While dobutamine can support cardiac function, it is not specific for treating local anesthetic toxicity and does not address the underlying cause.

 

Option D. CPR & Start NaHCO3 infusion: Sodium bicarbonate is used to treat metabolic acidosis and certain poisonings, such as tricyclic antidepressant overdose, but it is not specific for local anesthetic toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), immediate management includes starting CPR and administering 20% intravenous lipid emulsion (Intralipid) therapy. This approach helps to rapidly reduce the toxic effects of the local anesthetic on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.

questions.text: Decreased sexual maturity and hypogonadism seen with deficiency of: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc

 

Zinc is an essential trace element involved in numerous aspects of cellular metabolism. It plays a vital role in immune function, protein synthesis, wound healing, DNA synthesis, and cell division. Zinc is also crucial for normal growth and development during pregnancy, childhood, and adolescence, and it is necessary for the proper functioning of taste and smell.

 

Features of Zinc Deficiency:

 

  • Decreased Sexual Maturity: Zinc deficiency in children and adolescents can lead to growth retardation and delayed sexual maturation, particularly hypogonadism in males.
  • Hypogonadism: This condition is characterized by the underdevelopment of primary or secondary sexual characteristics, such as the testes in males, leading to delayed or absent puberty.
  • Impaired Immune Function: Zinc deficiency can result in an increased susceptibility to infections.
  • Other Symptoms: Include hair loss, diarrhea, delayed wound healing, and eye and skin lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper: Deficiency can lead to anemia (microcytic, hypochromic), neutropenia, bone abnormalities, and neurological issues such as peripheral neuropathy and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord.

 

Option C. Selenium: Deficiency can cause Keshan disease (a type of cardiomyopathy) and Kashin-Beck disease (a type of osteoarthropathy).

 

Option D. Iron: Deficiency is commonly associated with microcytic, hypochromic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency is associated with decreased sexual maturity and hypogonadism, particularly in male children, and is a common nutritional deficiency in developing countries. It is also linked to impaired growth, immune dysfunction, and delayed wound healing.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease has elevated serum creatinine and urea levels. Which of the following oral hypoglycemic agents is safe to use? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Linagliptin

 

Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) require careful selection of hypoglycemic agents due to altered drug excretion and the risk of further renal impairment. Among the given options, linagliptin is the safest choice for such patients. Linagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor that does not require dose adjustment in patients with renal impairment, including those on hemodialysis. This is because linagliptin is primarily excreted via the liver rather than the kidneys.

 

Note – Certain GLP-1 receptor agonists like liraglutide, dulaglutide, and semaglutide can be used without dose adjustment according to the latest studies. Additionally, pioglitazone can also be used without dose adjustment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glimepiride: This sulfonylurea can cause hypoglycemia and requires dose adjustment in patients with renal impairment, making it less suitable for those with elevated serum creatinine and urea levels.

 

Option B. Exenatide: This GLP-1 receptor agonist is contraindicated in patients with severe renal impairment (creatinine clearance <30 mL/min) due to the risk of accumulation and potential toxicity.

 

Option C. Vildagliptin: Another DPP-4 inhibitor, vildagliptin requires dose adjustment in renal impairment, making it less favorable compared to linagliptin for patients with CKD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Linagliptin is the preferred oral hypoglycemic agent for patients with diabetes and chronic kidney disease, as it does not require dose adjustment and is safely excreted by the liver.

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets. Arterial blood gas revealed acidosis. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Deferoxamine

 

Iron overdose, particularly with ferrous sulfate tablets, can lead to severe toxicity. Ingesting more than 60 mg/kg of elemental iron is considered potentially lethal. Acute iron poisoning presents with gastrointestinal symptoms initially and can progress to metabolic acidosis, shock, and multi-organ failure.

 

The presence of acidosis on arterial blood gas analysis is an important indicator of severe iron toxicity and an indication for the administration of an antidote. The appropriate antidote for acute iron intoxication is deferoxamine. Deferoxamine chelates free iron, forming a water-soluble complex that is excreted in the urine, thereby reducing iron's toxic effects on the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Activated charcoal: Activated charcoal is not effective in cases of iron poisoning. It does not adsorb metals like iron and can be harmful in certain situations like heavy metal poisoning, alcohols, petroleum products, and caustic substances.

 

Option C. Dimercaprol: Dimercaprol is used for chelation therapy in heavy metal poisoning (e.g., arsenic, mercury, gold) but is not effective for iron poisoning.

 

Option D. Penicillamine: Penicillamine is another chelating agent, typically used for conditions such as Wilson's disease (copper overload) and rheumatoid arthritis. It is not effective in treating iron toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of acute iron intoxication with signs of toxicity such as acidosis, the antidote of choice is deferoxamine. Activated charcoal is not effective in iron poisoning and should not be used.

questions.text:
A patient comes to ED with fever and headache. On examination, he has neck stiffness. CSF analysis was done and it shows the following findings. Most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS NOV 2018)

 

  • Opening pressure- increased
  • Proteins- mildly increased
  • Glucose – normal
  • Lymphocytes- increased
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coxsackie

 

The CSF findings indicative of increased lymphocytes, normal glucose levels, and mildly increased protein are characteristic of viral meningitis. Coxsackie virus, a common cause of viral meningitis, often presents with these CSF findings. The typical profile of viral meningitis includes normal glucose levels, which helps differentiate it from bacterial, fungal, and tuberculous meningitis where glucose levels are often decreased.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TB: Tuberculous meningitis typically shows low glucose, high protein, and a mixed cellular response in the CSF, which does not match the patient's CSF profile.

 

Option B. Neisseria gonorrhea: Generally causes bacterial meningitis with a different CSF profile—low glucose, high protein, and predominantly polymorphonuclear cells.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus: Fungal meningitis also shows low glucose and is not consistent with the normal glucose levels observed in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A female patient presents with severe restlessness, palpitations, and tremors to the emergency department. She is a known case of bronchial asthma. On examination, the neck looks swollen. Blood pressure is elevated, and tachycardia is noted. ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs is used for immediate management in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Diltiazem

 

In a patient with atrial fibrillation and bronchial asthma, the primary goal is to control the heart rate. For rate control in atrial fibrillation, beta-blockers and non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (NDCCBs) like diltiazem or verapamil are commonly used. However, in this case, the patient has bronchial asthma, which makes the use of beta-blockers (such as propranolol and esmolol) less suitable due to their potential to exacerbate asthma symptoms.

 

Diltiazem is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that effectively controls the heart rate without affecting bronchial muscle tone, making it a safer option for patients with asthma. Therefore, diltiazem is the drug of choice for immediate management in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker, which can exacerbate bronchial asthma by causing bronchoconstriction. Thus, it is not a suitable choice for patients with asthma.

 

Option C. Esmolol: Similar to propranolol, esmolol is a beta-blocker and can worsen asthma symptoms due to its bronchoconstrictive effects, making it unsuitable for this patient.

 

Option D. Propylthiouracil: This medication is used in the management of thyroid storm, a condition associated with severe hyperthyroidism. It is not relevant for rate control in atrial fibrillation and does not address the immediate needs of this patient's condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For immediate rate control in atrial fibrillation in a patient with bronchial asthma, non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers like diltiazem are preferred over beta-blockers to avoid exacerbating asthma symptoms.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man, post-MI, had the following lab values. Which of the following must be his treatment plan? (AIIMS MAY 2017)

 

LDL - 125mg/dl

 

HDL - 33mg/dl

 

TGL - 270mg/dl
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atorvastatin 80 mg

 

Post-MI patients require aggressive management to reduce the risk of future cardiovascular events. The lab values indicate elevated LDL and triglycerides, along with low HDL. The treatment plan includes the use of high-intensity statin therapy, which is recommended to significantly lower LDL cholesterol as part of secondary prevention strategies in atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD). Atorvastatin 80 mg falls under the category of high-intensity statins and is effective in lowering LDL cholesterol significantly, which helps in reducing the risk of recurrent cardiovascular events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rosuvastatin + fenofibrate: This combination might be considered if there were specific concerns about triglyceride levels that could not be managed by statin therapy alone. However, the primary goal post-MI is to manage LDL levels aggressively with high-intensity statins.

 

Option C. Fenofibrate: Fenofibrate primarily targets triglycerides and would not be the first choice when the primary objective is to lower LDL cholesterol post-MI.

 

Option D. Rosuvastatin 10 mg: While rosuvastatin is effective in lowering LDL cholesterol, a lower dose may not be sufficient for high-risk patients post-MI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The high-intensity statin therapy, such as atorvastatin 80 mg, is essential in the management of patients after an MI to reduce the risk of subsequent cardiovascular events, regardless of initial cholesterol levels. This approach aligns with guidelines that emphasize aggressive LDL reduction in patients with established cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best test for long-term control of diabetes? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HbA1C

 

HbA1C, also known as glycated hemoglobin, is the best test for assessing long-term control of diabetes. It reflects the average blood glucose levels over the past 2 to 3 months. This is because the lifespan of a red blood cell (RBC) is approximately 90 to 120 days, and HbA1C measures the percentage of hemoglobin that is glycated (coated with sugar). Therefore, it provides a comprehensive view of a patient's blood glucose control over a longer period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycated Albumin: Glycated albumin reflects blood glucose control over a shorter period, typically the last 2 to 3 weeks. While it can be useful in certain situations, it does not provide as long-term a view as HbA1C.

 

Option C. Urine sugar: Measuring sugar in the urine is not a reliable method for assessing long-term glucose control. It only indicates that the blood glucose level has been high enough to spill over into the urine, which reflects immediate/ recent glucose levels.

 

Option D. Fasting blood sugar: Fasting blood sugar provides information about the blood glucose level at a single point in time, typically after an overnight fast. It is useful for diagnosing diabetes and assessing short-term control but does not reflect long-term glucose control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HbA1C is the best test for evaluating long-term control of diabetes, providing an average of blood glucose levels over the past 2 to 3 months.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with long-standing type 2 diabetes came to the OPD with complaints of fatigue and frequent urination. His FBS = 144 mg/dl & PPBS = 210 mg/dl. What is the target HbA1c for adequate control of diabetes? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) < 7.0

 

Explanation

 

The universal target HbA1c for adequate control of diabetes is generally less than 7%. This target helps in reducing the risk of diabetic complications. However, it is important to consider individual patient factors when setting targets.

 

In very old and frail patients, a less stringent target of less than 8% may be appropriate to avoid the risks of hypoglycemia and other complications. Since the options do not include 8%, the standard target of less than 7% is selected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The target HbA1c for most patients with diabetes to ensure adequate control is less than 7%, though this may vary based on individual patient circumstances.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old medical student developed epistaxis that resolved spontaneously. He has been afebrile for the last 24 hours and his platelet count is 14,000/µL. His BP is 110/70 mm of Hg and there is a 28% rise in hematocrit. What should be the management? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

1. Give 4 units of platelets

2. Give plenty of oral fluids

3. Give IV fluids

4. Keep under observation

5. Discharge the patient
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3 and 4

 

The patient likely has Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever, indicated by a significant rise in hematocrit, which suggests plasma leakage during the critical phase of the illness. The management strategy includes:

 

  • Statement 2. Oral fluids to maintain hydration but must be balanced to avoid fluid overload.
  • Statement 3. IV fluids are essential for the management of severe dengue to correct the plasma leakage and prevent shock.
  • Statement 4. Observation is crucial to monitor for further complications such as dengue shock syndrome.

 

Option A. 1 and 2: Platelet transfusion is generally reserved for severe bleeding or very low platelet counts (typically <10,000/µL without bleeding). This patient's platelet count, while low, does not alone justify transfusion without signs of active or severe bleeding.

 

Option C. 1, 2 and 4: Includes unnecessary platelet transfusion without the clear presence of severe bleeding or extremely low platelet counts.

 

Option D. 2 and 5: Discharging the patient is inappropriate given the potential for rapid deterioration during the critical phase of dengue fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In dengue hemorrhagic fever, management focuses on careful fluid management and close observation during the critical phase to prevent or manage complications such as shock. Platelet transfusions are not routinely given based solely on low counts but are reserved for cases of significant clinical bleeding or extremely low platelet counts.

 

Note - There is no correlation between bleeding manifestation and platelet count.

 

Reference - Dengue Case management for Clinicians- CDC

questions.text: Nasal polyps are commonly associated with: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Intrinsic asthma

 

Intrinsic asthma, also known as non-allergic asthma, is often associated with nasal polyps. This type of asthma does not have an allergic or atopic component and tends to develop in adulthood. Intrinsic asthma is characterized by a non-IgE mediated pathway involving eosinophils and neutrophils, often triggered by non-allergic factors such as viral infections, stress, or exercise. Nasal polyps in this context are linked to chronic inflammation of the sinuses and nasal passages, common in non-allergic forms of asthma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Brittle asthma: This is a term used to describe a severe form of asthma where patients experience frequent, severe exacerbations. While serious, it does not specifically correlate with the presence of nasal polyps more than other types of asthma.

 

Option C. Extrinsic asthma: Known as allergic asthma, it is mediated by IgE and typically involves allergen triggers like pollen, dust mites, and molds. Nasal polyps are less commonly associated with this subtype compared to intrinsic asthma.

 

Option D. Exercise-induced asthma: This condition, characterized by bronchoconstriction triggered by physical activity, is not typically associated with nasal polyps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Pulmonology/Asthma/Chap 287

questions.text:
Correct sequence after p wave: (INICET NOV 2020)

 

A- 'a' wave

B- 1st heart sound

C-Rapid filling of ventricles

D- 't' wave
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ABDC

 

Following the P wave, which represents atrial depolarization leading to atrial contraction:

 

A- 'a' wave occurs as a result of atrial contraction, pushing blood into the ventricles.

 

B- 1st heart sound is produced by the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves at the beginning of ventricular systole.

 

D- 't' wave represents the repolarization of the ventricles, indicating the beginning of ventricular relaxation.

 

C- Rapid filling of ventricles follows as the ventricles relax and the atrioventricular valves open, allowing blood to flow from the higher pressure atria to the relaxed ventricles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Electrical events precede mechanical events in cardiac homeostasis

 

P wave→ Atrial contraction (a wave).

 

QRS→ ventricular contraction (C wave)

 

T wave→ Ventricular relaxation (Early rapid filling (Y descent)

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/Clinical/ chap 239

choices.text: A patient who died during transportation to the hospital
A patient who died after failed resuscitation after reaching the hospital
A patient who was brought dead to the hospital
A patient who is awaiting death in the hospital

questions.text: Which of the following patients comes under the category III non-heart-beating donor? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A patient who is awaiting death in the hospital

 

Non-heart beating donor = Donation after circulatory death (DCD)

 

Category III non-heart-beating donors, also known as Donation after Circulatory Death (DCD), specifically refers to patients who are anticipated to have an imminent cardiac arrest, usually while in the hospital. These patients are often on ventilator support, and the decision to withdraw life-sustaining treatment is made due to irreversible medical conditions. The donation process is planned, and organs are procured once circulatory death is confirmed following the withdrawal of support.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A patient who died during transportation to the hospital: This would typically fall under Category I (Dead on Arrival) if they arrive with irreversible cardiac arrest.

 

Option B. A patient who died after failed resuscitation after reaching the hospital: This falls under Category II, which involves unsuccessful resuscitation efforts in the emergency room.

 

Option C. A patient who was brought dead to the hospital: Similar to option A, this is classified under Category I.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Modified Maastricht Classification categorizes DCD:

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Renal transplantation/Table 313-1.

questions.text: An elderly woman is brought to the OPD with complaints of behavioral change, a history of multiple falls, urinary incontinence, and dementia. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Normal pressure hydrocephalus

 

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) is characterized by the triad of dementia, gait disturbance (typically apraxia or magnetic gait), and urinary incontinence. This condition often involves enlargement of the cerebral ventricles due to cerebrospinal fluid accumulation, which can exert pressure on surrounding brain structures, particularly affecting the frontal lobes responsible for cognitive and urinary control. The clinical presentation aligns well with the symptoms described in the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontotemporal dementia: This condition often presents with prominent personality changes and language difficulties rather than the classic triad seen in NPH. Falls are less commonly associated with this form of dementia in its early stages.

 

Option C. Parkinson disease: Typically presents with motor symptoms such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. While dementia can occur in later stages, it is not typically accompanied by urinary incontinence and would not explain the early presence of falls as the primary symptom.

 

Option D. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease: Known for rapid progression of neurological symptoms including dementia, myoclonus (sudden muscle spasms), and significant motor dysfunction. It progresses much faster than what is typically seen in NPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NPH is characterized by Dementia, Apraxia/Magnetic gait with urinary incontinence due to frontal lobe dysfunction

 

Reference - Harrison/Dementia/Chap 434

choices.text: TPE removes the von Willebrand factor
TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases ADAMTS protease activity

questions.text: Total plasma exchange is done in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. How does TPE help in the management of TTP? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases ADAMTS protease activity

 

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is caused by a deficiency of ADAMTS13, usually due to autoantibodies. Total plasma exchange (TPE) removes these autoantibodies, thereby increasing ADAMTS13 protease activity and preventing the accumulation of large von Willebrand factor multimers. This results in platelet trapping. Classic clinical picture includes:

 

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA)
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • End-organ damage (neurological injury)
  • Fever

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. TPE removes the von Willebrand factor: Incorrect; the goal is to remove autoantibodies.
 

Option B. TPE removes the antiplatelet antibodies: Incorrect; TTP involves anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies.
 

Option C. TPE replenishes the coagulation factors: Incorrect; TTP is not primarily a coagulation factor deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TPE in TTP primarily removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies, increasing ADAMTS13 activity and reducing microthrombi formation.

questions.text: Identify the sign? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Babinski sign


The Babinski sign is a reflex response where the big toe extends upward and the other toes fan out upon stimulation of the sole. This indicates an upper motor neuron lesion.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Ankle jerk: Reflex action at the ankle joint.
 

Option C. Jendrassik: Maneuver to enhance reflexes.
 

Option D. Normal plantar response: Flexion of all toes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive Babinski sign indicates an upper motor neuron lesion.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presented with an acute onset of chest pain radiating to the left arm and diaphoresis. His ECG and cardiac biomarkers show non-ST elevation myocardial infarction. Which of the following will be used in the treatment of this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

1. Atorvastatin 

2. Aspirin 

3. Clopidogrel 

4. Low molecular weight heparin 

5. Alteplase
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:  

 

In the management of non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), several medications are routinely used to reduce the risk of further ischemic events and manage the condition effectively:

 

  1. Atorvastatin: High-intensity statin therapy is recommended to lower cholesterol levels and stabilize atherosclerotic plaques.
  2. Aspirin: This antiplatelet agent is essential for reducing clot formation and preventing further arterial blockage.
  3. Clopidogrel: Another antiplatelet agent, often used in combination with aspirin, to provide dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT), which is beneficial in preventing further ischemic events.
  4. Low molecular weight heparin: Anticoagulant therapy, such as enoxaparin, is crucial in preventing thrombus formation and managing NSTEMI. Enoxaparin is typically administered subcutaneously at a dose of 1 mg/kg twice daily.

 

Other Option:

 

5. Alteplase: This thrombolytic agent is used in the management of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) when percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is not immediately available. It is not indicated for NSTEMI due to the lack of ST elevation and the associated risks of bleeding without significant benefit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For NSTEMI management, the treatment includes Atorvastatin, Aspirin, Clopidogrel, and Low molecular weight heparin. Thrombolytic agents like Alteplase are reserved for STEMI with specific indications.

questions.text: Noninvasive test to detect hepatic fibrosis include? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibro test

 

The FibroTest, also known as the Fibro test, is a noninvasive, blood-based test designed specifically to detect hepatic fibrosis. This test calculates the degree of liver fibrosis using a combination of several serum biochemical markers including haptoglobin, bilirubin, gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT), apolipoprotein A1, and alpha-2 macroglobulin. It evaluates liver damage and fibrosis by measuring these markers, which are affected by liver function and architecture changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspartate aminotransferases /platelet ratio (APRI): Incorrect as it is primarily used to estimate the likelihood or severity of fibrosis rather than to directly detect it. It correlates with the degree of liver fibrosis but is less specific.

 

Option C. Forns index: Incorrect for the same reason as APRI. The Forns index is used to assess the risk of developing liver fibrosis based on variables including age, platelet count, cholesterol levels, and GGT, but it does not directly measure fibrosis.

 

Option D. Serum laminin & serum hyaluronidase: Incorrect as these are not standard tests for directly detecting hepatic fibrosis; they can indicate changes in extracellular matrix turnover but are less specific and commonly used compared to the FibroTest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibro test is a sensitive test to detect hepatic fibrosis. It is a multiparameter blood test which incorporate haptoglobin, bilirubin, GGT, apolipoprotein A1, and alpha-2 macroglobulin.

 

Test for estimating risk developing hepatic fibrosis:

 

  1. AST/platelet ratio
  2. Forns index
  3. Fib-4
  4. Cirrhosis determinant score.

 

Test for detecting hepatic fibrosis: Fibro test.

questions.text: A male patient was brought to the emergency room with complaints of headache, vomiting, and blurring of vision after he consumed some locally produced spirit. Which of the following is used for the treatment of his condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fomepizole

 

The symptoms of headache, vomiting, and blurring of vision after consuming locally produced spirit suggest methanol poisoning. Methanol is commonly found in illicit liquor and can cause severe toxicity.

 

The treatment for methanol poisoning involves inhibiting the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase, which is responsible for converting methanol into its toxic metabolites, such as formic acid and formaldehyde.

 

Fomepizole (4-methylpyrazole) is the drug of choice as it is a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing the formation of these toxic metabolites.

 

Alternative treatment – IV Ethanol (competitive blocker of alcohol dehydrogenase)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flumazenil: Used as an antidote for benzodiazepine overdose.

 

Option C. Diazepam: Used in the management of alcohol withdrawal and as a sedative but not as an antidote for methanol poisoning.

 

Option D. Naloxone: Used as an antidote for opioid overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fomepizole is the preferred treatment for methanol poisoning, as it inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing the formation of toxic metabolites.

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures. His CT head reveals multiple parenchymal cysts. Which of the following is not a part of immediate management in the next 24 hours? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antiparasitic drugs

 

Explanation:

 

Antiparasitic drugs, such as albendazole or praziquantel, are not part of the immediate management. Starting antiparasitic treatment without adequate anti-inflammatory coverage (steroids) can worsen the patient's condition by increasing inflammation due to the destruction of the cysts.

 

Antiparasitic therapy (albendazole or praziquantel or both) can be initiated later, typically along with steroids, to mitigate this risk.

 

Doses –

 

  • Albendazole – 15 mg/Kg/day (Max. of 1200 mg/day)
  • Praziquantel – 50-100 mg/kg/day in 3 divided doses

 

Note – Severe disease or >2 cyst – Combination of both drug in doses of 15 mg/kg/day Albendazole + 50mg/kg/day Praziquantel

 

Other Options:

 

In a case of neurocysticercosis, the immediate management of a patient presenting with seizures and multiple parenchymal cysts on CT includes:

 

Option B. Steroids: To reduce inflammation and surrounding edema caused by the cysts.

 

Option C. Antiepileptics: To control seizures, which are the most common presentation of neurocysticercosis.

 

Option D. Anti-edema treatment: To manage any cerebral edema and prevent further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the immediate management of neurocysticercosis presenting with seizures, antiepileptics, steroids, and anti-edema treatment are essential, while antiparasitic drugs can be started later.

questions.text: AIDS-defining malignancies include all except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Melanoma

 

Melanoma, on the other hand, is a type of skin cancer primarily associated with UV exposure and is not considered an AIDS-defining malignancy. Although people with HIV/AIDS might have a higher risk of developing melanoma due to their immunocompromised state, it is not specifically used to define AIDS.

 

AIDS-defining malignancies are specific types of cancer that are more likely to occur in people with AIDS. These cancers are used in the clinical definition of AIDS because they are directly associated with the immunosuppression caused by the HIV virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kaposi's sarcoma: This cancer is caused by Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and is one of the most common AIDS-defining cancers. It manifests as vascular tumors that can appear on the skin and internal organs.

 

Option C. Invasive cervical carcinoma: This cancer is linked to the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) and is considered an AIDS-defining condition due to the increased risk in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma: Particularly the diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) and primary central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma, are common in AIDS patients due to the compromised immune system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melanoma is not considered an AIDS-defining malignancy, unlike Kaposi's sarcoma, invasive cervical carcinoma, and non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred neoadjuvant therapy for a newly diagnosed GIST with PDGFRA D842V mutation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Avapritinib

 

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) with PDGFRA D842V mutation are notably resistant to imatinib therapy. Avapritinib is specifically approved for GIST patients with PDGFRA D842V mutations, as it shows significant activity against this particular mutation. This drug can be used in both neoadjuvant and metastatic settings for these specific cases.

 

The approval was based on the NAVIGATOR trial, which showed remarkable response rates in patients with PDGFRA D842V-mutant GIST, making it the preferred choice for this specific molecular subtype.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prednisolone: Prednisolone is a corticosteroid with no direct antineoplastic activity against GISTs. It may be used supportively but is not a primary treatment option.

 

Option B. Imatinib: While imatinib is the standard first-line treatment for most GISTs, it is specifically ineffective against PDGFRA D842V mutations due to structural changes in the binding site.

 

Option D. Indomethacin: Indomethacin is an NSAID used for pain management and has no role in GIST treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The molecular subtypes of GIST is crucial for selecting appropriate targeted therapy. While imatinib is effective for most GISTs, specific mutations like PDGFRA D842V require alternative targeted agents like avapritinib for optimal treatment outcomes.

choices.text: It is a complication of measles virus infection
Its incidence has decreased after the introduction of vaccination
It most commonly affects individuals between 5 and 15 years old
It typically presents initially with fever and headache

questions.text: Which of the following statements about subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is NOT correct? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. It typically presents initially with fever and headache

 

Explanation:

 

SSPE is a rare, progressive neurological disorder caused by a persistent measles virus infection that leads to brain inflammation and neurodegeneration. The disease typically has an insidious onset with subtle behavioral and intellectual deterioration rather than acute symptoms like fever and headache.

 

SSPE presents with progressive cognitive decline, personality changes, and school performance deterioration as the initial manifestations. This is followed by myoclonus, ataxia, and eventually a vegetative state. The absence of fever and headache as initial presenting features distinguishes it from acute viral encephalitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a complication of measles virus infection: This statement is correct. SSPE is caused by a persistent infection with a defective measles virus that remains dormant in the CNS for years after the initial infection before causing progressive neurodegeneration.

 

Option B. Its incidence has decreased after the introduction of vaccination: This statement is correct. The introduction of measles vaccination has significantly reduced the incidence of SSPE, as preventing the primary measles infection prevents the subsequent development of SSPE.

 

Option C. It most commonly affects individuals between 5 and 15 years old: This statement is correct. SSPE typically affects children and adolescents who had measles infection at a very young age, with disease onset usually occurring 6-8 years after the primary infection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SSPE presents with insidious behavioral and cognitive changes rather than acute symptoms like fever and headache, and represents a rare but devastating delayed complication of measles virus infection that has become increasingly uncommon due to vaccination.

choices.text: 1-5% of the population can have epileptiform discharges.
Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy.
Doing EEG is mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves.

questions.text: True about electroencephalogram (EEG) is all except: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Doing EEG is mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.

 

Electroencephalography (EEG) is a key diagnostic tool in the evaluation of neurological conditions, particularly epilepsy. However, it is not mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures. A patient can have seizures even if their EEG results are normal. An abnormal EEG can provide reassurance of a diagnosis of epilepsy when the clinical context supports it, but a normal EEG does not rule out epilepsy or seizures. Therefore, making an EEG mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1-5% of the population can have epileptiform discharges: This statement is correct. Epileptiform discharges can be present in a small percentage of the general population without necessarily indicating that the individual has epilepsy.

 

Option B. Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy: This statement is correct. Scalp EEG can indeed help localize the origin of epileptic activity, including frontal lobe epilepsy, although it might not always be definitive.

 

Option D. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves: This statement is correct. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) and other forms of encephalopathy can show triphasic waves and slow wave patterns on an EEG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EEG is not mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures as patients can have seizures even with a normal EEG.

questions.text: A child presented with dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cretinism

 

The child presents with symptoms that are highly characteristic of congenital hypothyroidism, also known as cretinism. These symptoms include dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia (enlarged tongue), and umbilical hernia. Congenital hypothyroidism is a condition that arises from insufficient thyroid hormone production at birth. If untreated, it can lead to mental retardation and developmental delays. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent long-term adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prader-Willi syndrome: This genetic disorder is characterized by hypotonia, feeding difficulties in infancy, followed by hyperphagia and obesity in childhood, intellectual disability, and characteristic facial features. It does not typically present with macroglossia or umbilical hernia.

 

Option C. Edward syndrome: Also known as Trisomy 18, Edward syndrome presents with severe intellectual disability, congenital heart defects, and distinct facial features. While it can present with a range of symptoms, dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia are not typical features.

 

Option D. Galactosemia: This metabolic disorder is due to an inability to metabolize galactose properly. Symptoms include jaundice, vomiting, poor weight gain, and lethargy. It does not typically present with macroglossia, dry skin, or rough hair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cretinism, or congenital hypothyroidism, should be considered in infants presenting with dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent long-term developmental delays.

questions.text: All of the following contribute to the circle of death, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Femoral artery

 

Explanation:

 

The "circle of death" refers to the vascular anastomotic ring formed around the femoral ring, which is critical during femoral hernia and laparoscopic inguinal hernia surgery. This dangerous vascular circle is formed by the obturator artery, aberrant obturator artery (when present), and inferior epigastric artery. The femoral artery does not contribute to this vascular circle - it runs lateral to the femoral vein and outside the femoral ring.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Obturator artery: This vessel normally originates from the internal iliac artery and contributes to the vascular anastomosis around the femoral ring.
  • Option B. Aberrant Obturator artery: When present, this anomalous vessel arises from the inferior epigastric artery (instead of from the internal iliac) and courses around the femoral ring to reach the obturator foramen, creating a significant surgical risk.
  • Option C. Inferior Epigastric artery: This vessel runs along the medial border of the deep inguinal ring and can anastomose with the obturator artery, forming part of the "circle of death."

 

Femoral region anatomy relevant to hernias: The femoral ring has rigid boundaries including the inguinal ligament superiorly, femoral vein laterally, pubic arc (pecten pubis) inferiorly, and lacunar ligament medially. The contents of the femoral canal include fat and the lymph node of Cloquet.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

During femoral hernia repair, particularly when making an incision in the lacunar ligament to relieve strangulation, surgeons must be extremely cautious of the "circle of death" formed by the obturator and inferior epigastric vessels - not the femoral artery.

questions.text: Calcitonin levels are increased in: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hyperparathyroidism

 

Calcitonin, a hormone secreted by the thyroid gland, is involved in the regulation of calcium levels in the body. In conditions where there is an increase in parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, such as in hyperparathyroidism, there is a corresponding increase in blood calcium levels. The body responds to this hypercalcemia by increasing the secretion of calcitonin to help lower the calcium levels back to normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperthyroidism: While hyperthyroidism involves the thyroid gland, it does not typically result in increased calcitonin levels. Hyperthyroidism mainly increases thyroid hormones like thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3), not calcitonin.

 

Option B. Hypoparathyroidism: This condition is characterized by decreased PTH levels, leading to hypocalcemia (low calcium levels), not hypercalcemia that would stimulate calcitonin production.

 

Option D. Cushing's syndrome: Cushing's syndrome involves an excess of cortisol, a steroid hormone, and does not directly affect calcitonin levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased calcitonin levels are typically seen in response to hypercalcemia, as seen in hyperparathyroidism. This is a compensatory mechanism to help maintain calcium homeostasis.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child with a history of GTCS presented with 4-5 episodes of seizures, and seizures are present for more than 45 minutes. What will be the most appropriate management for this patient?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam followed by levetiracetam

 

Explanation:

 

In the management of status epilepticus (SE), the first line of treatment involves benzodiazepines. Lorazepam is preferred due to its rapid onset and longer duration of action compared to other benzodiazepines like diazepam or midazolam.

 

  • First line treatment: Intravenous (IV) lorazepam (standard dose of 4 mg in adults; different doses for children).
  • If seizures persist after the first dose of lorazepam, it can be repeated once.
  • Second line treatment: If seizures continue after two doses of lorazepam, IV anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs) are administered. Options include IV phenytoin, fosphenytoin, levetiracetam, valproate, or lacosamide.
  • If still persist, intubate the patient, continuous EEG monitoring and give IV General anaesthesia (IV midazolam or IV propofol infusion)

 

In this case, following lorazepam with levetiracetam is consistent with current guidelines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Levetiracetam followed by valproate: Levetiracetam is a second-line treatment, not first-line.

 

Option C. Carbamazepine followed by lorazepam: Carbamazepine is not typically used in the acute management of SE.

 

Option D. Valproate followed by gabapentin: Valproate can be used as a second-line treatment, but gabapentin is not typically used for SE management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first line of management for status epilepticus is IV lorazepam, followed by IV antiepileptic drugs like levetiracetam if seizures persist.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male on tuberculosis treatment presents with complaints of peripheral numbness and tingling sensation in both feet. He also reports difficulty walking, especially in the dark. Which drug is likely to cause these side effects? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isoniazid

 

Isoniazid (INH) is known to cause peripheral neuropathy due to its interference with pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) metabolism. The neuropathy typically presents as symmetrical sensory deficits affecting the distal extremities, particularly the feet. Symptoms include numbness, tingling sensations, and impaired proprioception leading to difficulty walking, especially in low-light conditions. This side effect can be prevented or treated by supplementing with pyridoxine (Vitamin B6).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rifampicin: While rifampicin can cause various side effects including hepatotoxicity and red-orange discoloration of body fluids, it is not associated with peripheral neuropathy.

 

Option C. Pyrazinamide: This drug primarily causes arthralgia and hyperuricemia. It is not known to cause neurological symptoms.

 

Option D. Ethambutol: While ethambutol is known for causing optic neuritis and visual disturbances, it does not typically cause peripheral neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isoniazid-induced peripheral neuropathy is a common side effect that occurs due to vitamin B6 deficiency. It presents with symmetrical sensory symptoms in distal extremities and can be prevented by prophylactic pyridoxine supplementation.

questions.text: Splenectomy is contraindicated in which of the following conditions? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary splenic lymphoma

 

Primary splenic lymphoma should initially be treated with systemic chemotherapy (R-CHOP), making splenectomy contraindicated as first-line treatment. Splenectomy in untreated lymphoma can lead to disease dissemination and complicate staging and response assessment. Additionally, splenectomy before chemotherapy may increase the risk of complications during subsequent treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splenic rupture: Splenectomy is often necessary in traumatic splenic rupture, especially in hemodynamically unstable patients or when conservative management fails.

 

Option C. Hairy cell leukemia: Splenectomy may be indicated in cases of massive symptomatic splenomegaly or when there's no response to standard therapy with purine analogs.

 

Option D. Hereditary spherocytosis: Splenectomy is actually beneficial in hereditary spherocytosis as it removes the primary site of red cell destruction and can lead to resolution of anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary splenic lymphoma represents a contraindication to immediate splenectomy as it requires systemic chemotherapy as first-line treatment, with surgery potentially compromising staging and therapeutic outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs can increase glucose excretion in urine? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Empagliflozin

 

Explanation:

 

Empagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor.

 

Drugs in this class (such as empagliflozin, canagliflozin, and dapagliflozin) inhibit the sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) in the kidneys, leading to increased glucose excretion in the urine (glycosuria). This helps lower blood glucose levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glimepiride: A sulfonylurea that stimulates insulin release from the pancreas.

 

Option B. Liraglutide: A GLP-1 receptor agonist that increases insulin secretion, slows gastric emptying, and promotes satiety.

 

Option C. Acarbose: An alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that delays carbohydrate absorption in the intestines, leading to increased excretion of undigested carbohydrates in the stools.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Empagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, increases glucose excretion in the urine by inhibiting the sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 in the kidneys.

questions.text: What is the Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) class for the patient who has a serum bilirubin 2.5 mg/dl, serum albumin 3 g/dL, prothrombin time 5 seconds (INR = 2), no encephalopathy, and mild ascites? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Class B

 

To determine the Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) score, each of the five clinical measures is scored with points from 1 to 3 based on specific criteria:

 

  1. Bilirubin:
    • <2 mg/dL = 1 point
    • 2-3 mg/dL = 2 points (Patient has 2.5 mg/dL)
    • 3 mg/dL = 3 points
  2. Albumin:
    • 3.5 g/dL = 1 point
    • 2.8-3.5 g/dL = 2 points
    • <2.8 g/dL = 3 points (Patient has 3 g/dL, scoring 2 points)
  3. INR:
    • 1-1.7 = 1 point
    • 1.8-2.3 = 2 points (Patient has INR = 2)
    • 2.3 = 3 points
  4. Ascites:
    • None = 1 point
    • Controlled = 2 points (Patient has mild ascites, scoring 2 points)
    • Refractory = 3 points
  5. Encephalopathy:
    • None = 1 point (Patient has none)
    • Grade 1-2 = 2 points
    • Grade 3-4 = 3 points

 

Scoring Calculation:

 

  • Bilirubin = 2 points
  • Albumin = 2 points
  • INR = 2 points
  • Ascites = 2 points
  • Encephalopathy = 1 point
    Total = 9 points

The patient scores 9 points, placing them in Child-Turcotte-Pugh Class B.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Child-Turcotte-Pugh scoring system

 

 

Inference:

 

  • CTP A: 5-6
  • CTP B: 7-9
  • CTP C: 10-15

 

Reference - Harrison/Cirrhosis/Chapter 344

questions.text: Which gene defect causes familial hyperlipidemia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDLr

 

Familial hyperlipidemia, particularly familial hypercholesterolemia (FH), is a genetic disorder characterized by high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the blood. The primary cause of this condition is mutations in the LDL receptor (LDLr) gene.

 

Mechanism of Action: The LDL receptor is responsible for the uptake of LDL cholesterol from the blood into the liver. When there are mutations in the LDLr gene, the receptors are either dysfunctional or deficient. As a result, LDL cholesterol cannot be effectively removed from the bloodstream, leading to elevated levels of LDL cholesterol. This condition significantly increases the risk of atherosclerosis and cardiovascular diseases.

 

  • Heterozygous FH: This form is more common and results in moderately high LDL cholesterol levels (200-300 mg/dL). It is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases.
  • Homozygous FH: This form is rarer and more severe, with LDL cholesterol levels potentially reaching 600-700 mg/dL. Individuals with homozygous FH have a very high risk of early cardiovascular events and death.

 

Other Options:
