Option A. ApoE:  Mutations in the ApoE gene cause familial dysbetalipoproteinemia (Type III hyperlipoproteinemia in Frederickson classification), which leads to elevated levels of intermediate-density lipoproteins (IDL) and is characterized by the presence of remnant particles in the blood.

 

Option B. ApoCII:  Deficiency in ApoCII causes familial chylomicronemia syndrome (Type I hyperlipoproteinemia in Frederickson classification). This condition is associated with extremely high levels of triglycerides due to impaired lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activation, which is necessary for the breakdown of triglycerides.

 

Option D. ApoB48:  ApoB48 is involved in the assembly and secretion of chylomicrons from the intestine. There is no known condition caused by a deficiency of ApoB48 that leads to familial hyperlipidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mutations in the LDL receptor (LDLr) gene cause familial hypercholesterolemia, a condition characterized by high levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood due to impaired clearance by the liver. This condition significantly increases the risk of cardiovascular diseases.

questions.text: Infertility in Kartagener's syndrome is due to which of the following? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Asthenospermia

 

Asthenospermia (Immotile sperm [Greek sthenos = strength]

 

Kartagener result from loss of function of axonemal dynein that impairs sperm motility. Respiratory Ciliary dysmotility leads to bronchiectasis and recurrent infections. Association of situs inversus is noted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oligospermia: Incorrect because while sperm count can be affected in some genetic or hormonal disorders, in Kartagener's syndrome, the sperm count is typically normal; the issue lies in their motility.

 

Option C. Epididymis obstruction: Incorrect as this is not a feature of Kartagener’s syndrome. While structural anomalies in the reproductive tract can lead to such issues, Kartagener’s syndrome specifically affects the motility of sperm due to ciliary dysfunction.

 

Option D. Undescended testes: Incorrect as undescended testes are not associated with Kartagener’s syndrome, which primarily affects ciliary function and not the anatomical position of the testes.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Infertility in Kartagener's syndrome is primarily due to asthenospermia, which is caused by the immobility of sperm. This immotility results from the genetic defect affecting the dynein arm of sperm flagella, similar to the defect affecting cilia in the respiratory tract, leading to the classic symptoms of the syndrome.

 

Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/Bronchiectasis/Chapter 290

questions.text:
A 40-year-old smoker who is a known case of hypertension was on enalapril and hydrochlorothiazide. He had an episode of hemoptysis and on evaluation, he was found to have bronchogenic carcinoma with brain metastasis. His lab values were Na-124mg/dL, creatinine - 2.8mg%, blood sugar 112mg/dL, blood urea - 24mg/dL, serum osmolality 255mosm, urine osmolality - 110 mosm, 24-hour urinary sodium - 110 and BP - 150/90 mmHg.

 

Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis of the low sodium values in him? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SIADH

 

Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH) is the most probable diagnosis in this patient. The diagnostic criteria and the patient's clinical presentation support this conclusion:

 

 

Additionally, lung cancer (specifically bronchogenic carcinoma) can often cause SIADH, either through ectopic production of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) or related paraneoplastic syndromes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diuretic induced hyponatremia: Incorrect because the pattern of serum and urine osmolality does not align solely with diuretic use; the high urine sodium and euvolemia are more indicative of SIADH.

 

Option C. Cerebral salt wasting syndrome: Incorrect as this condition typically presents with hypovolemia and low blood pressure due to significant sodium and fluid loss, which is not evident in this patient who maintains a normal blood pressure.

 

Option D. Pseudohyponatremia: Incorrect because the reduced serum osmolality directly indicates true hyponatremia, not a distortion caused by high levels of lipids or proteins in the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SIADH can be associated with malignancies like lung cancer, presenting with hyponatremia, low serum osmolality, and inappropriately concentrated urine despite the presence of low plasma osmolality. This clinical scenario should prompt consideration of SIADH, particularly in patients with known malignancies and typical lab findings.

choices.text: DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue
Upsetting of receptors so no treatment is required

questions.text: A patient came to the medical OPD with complaints of polyuria. He has a history of undergoing total hypophysectomy. His Na+ levels are found to be 155 mEq/L, urine osmolality was 200 mOsm/L. What is the definitive management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. DDAVP supplementation for lifelong

 

The patient's presentation of polyuria and low urine osmolality (200 mOsm/L) with hypernatremia (Na+ 155 mEq/L) is indicative of diabetes insipidus (DI). Given the history of total hypophysectomy, this is most likely central diabetes insipidus (CDI), where the pituitary gland no longer produces antidiuretic hormone (ADH, also known as vasopressin).

 

In CDI, the definitive treatment is desmopressin (DDAVP), a synthetic analog of ADH. Desmopressin helps to reduce urine output and correct hypernatremia by promoting water reabsorption in the kidneys. Since the condition is permanent due to the hypophysectomy, lifelong supplementation with desmopressin is necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue: Discontinuing DDAVP after 2 weeks is not appropriate as the patient will continue to suffer from polyuria and hypernatremia due to the lack of ADH.

 

Option C. Upsetting of receptors so no treatment is required: This option is incorrect as the patient's symptoms and lab findings clearly indicate the need for treatment.

 

Option D. Thiazides for 2 weeks: Thiazides are used in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) to reduce urine output by increasing ADH sensitivity. However, in central diabetes insipidus, thiazides are not effective because the issue is the absence of ADH, not a problem with the kidneys' response to it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with central diabetes insipidus following total hypophysectomy, lifelong desmopressin (DDAVP) supplementation is required to manage symptoms and prevent complications from persistent polyuria and hypernatremia.

questions.text: A 41-year-old construction worker in Uttar Pradesh collapsed at the construction site in the afternoon of a summer day. Which of the following is least likely to be seen? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sweating

 

The scenario describes a case of classic heat stroke, which is a medical emergency characterized by an elevated core body temperature (often above 104°F or 40°C) and central nervous system dysfunction due to exposure to high environmental temperatures.

 

Sweating is typically absent in classic heat stroke. This is because the body’s thermoregulatory mechanisms fail, and the skin becomes hot and dry. In contrast, in exertional heat stroke (which occurs during intense physical activity), sweating may still be present.

 

Other Options:

 

In classic heat stroke, particularly due to prolonged exposure to high environmental temperatures:

 

Option A. Temperature of 105°F: It is common to have very high body temperatures in heat stroke.

 

Option C. Hypotension: Can occur due to dehydration and vasodilation.

 

Option D. Tachypnea: Increased respiratory rate is a compensatory mechanism to help cool the body and deal with metabolic demands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In classic heat stroke, typically caused by high environmental temperatures, the patient often presents with high body temperature, hypotension, and tachypnea, but lacks sweating. This distinguishes it from exertional heat stroke, where sweating might still be present.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with anemia and has a history of rheumatoid arthritis on long-term treatment. His serum ferritin is elevated, and iron studies show low serum iron with low iron-binding capacity. What is the most likely cause of his anemia? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anemia of chronic disease

 

In patients with chronic inflammatory conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, anemia of chronic disease (ACD) is the most common cause of anemia. This type of anemia is characterized by impaired iron utilization despite normal or elevated iron stores. The inflammatory state leads to increased hepcidin production, which blocks iron release from storage sites and reduces iron absorption. The characteristic laboratory findings include elevated ferritin (acute phase reactant), low serum iron, and low total iron-binding capacity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia: While this is the most common cause of anemia in the general population, the elevated ferritin and pattern of iron studies in this case are inconsistent with iron deficiency.

 

Option C. Aplastic anemia: A rare condition causing pancytopenia due to bone marrow failure. The presentation and laboratory findings don't support this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Myelodysplastic syndrome: While more common in older adults, the presence of chronic inflammation and characteristic iron studies more strongly suggest anemia of chronic disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anemia of chronic disease is characterized by elevated ferritin, low serum iron, and low iron-binding capacity in the setting of chronic inflammatory conditions. This pattern helps distinguish it from iron deficiency anemia, where ferritin is typically low.

questions.text: MEN 1 syndrome is associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parathyroid adenoma

 

Explanation

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome, also known as Wermer's syndrome, is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the MEN1 gene. It is characterized by tumors in three primary endocrine glands, known as the "three Ps":

 

  1. Parathyroid adenoma: Leading to primary hyperparathyroidism.
  2. Pituitary adenoma: Most commonly prolactinomas.
  3. Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors: Which can include gastrinomas, insulinomas, and non-functioning pancreatic tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Parotid tumor and Option C. Renal cell carcinoma: Not associated with MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Option D. Pheochromocytoma: Associated with MEN 2A and MEN 2B syndromes, but not MEN 1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MEN 1 syndrome, also known as Wermer's syndrome, is associated with tumors in the parathyroid glands, pituitary gland, and pancreatic islet cells, with parathyroid adenoma being a common manifestation.

questions.text: A patient is a known case of hypertension and is on multiple antihypertensive drugs. His ECG is shown below. Which drug is responsible for the following ECG? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Spironolactone

 

The ECG shows tall, tented T waves, absent P waves (atrial standstill), and a severely widened QRS complex. These are classic signs of severe hyperkalemia.

 

Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that can cause hyperkalemia. It is known for increasing potassium levels in the blood by inhibiting the effects of aldosterone, leading to decreased excretion of potassium in the urine.

 

Therefore, the drug most likely responsible for the ECG findings is Spironolactone due to its potent potassium-sparing effects leading to severe hyperkalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hydrochlorothiazide: Causes hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Can cause mild hyperkalemia but not to the extent seen in the ECG.

 

Option D. Prazosin: Does not affect potassium levels significantly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spironolactone, a potassium-sparing diuretic, can cause severe hyperkalemia, which is characterized by tall, tented T waves, absent P waves, and widened QRS complexes on an ECG.

questions.text: What is not a feature of myasthenia gravis among the following? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Absent deep tendon reflexes.

 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by weakness and fatiguability of skeletal muscles. There is decrease in number of available acetylcholine receptors at neuromuscular junction due to an antibody mediated autoimmune attack.

 

  • Visual problems, including drooping eyelids (ptosis) and double vision (diplopia)
  • Muscle weakness and fatigue may vary rapidly in intensity over days or even hours and worsen as muscles are used (early fatigue)
  • Facial muscle involvement causing a mask-like appearance; a smile may appear more like a snarl
  • Trouble swallowing or pronouncing words
  • Weakness of the neck or limbs
  • Weakness increases during repeated use or late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep.
  • Deep tendon reflexes preserved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle fatigue: This is a defining symptom of MG, characterized by increased muscle weakness with continued activity.

 

Option C. Normal pupillary reflex: MG primarily affects voluntary muscles and typically does not impact the autonomic functions, including pupillary reflexes which remain normal.

 

Option D. Ptosis: Ptosis, or drooping eyelids, is one of the common features of MG due to muscle weakness affecting the muscles that control eyelid elevation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deep tendon reflexes are preserved in myasthenia gravis despite significant muscle weakness and fatigability, distinguishing it from other neuromuscular disorders that might also lead to reflex abnormalities.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented with a gradually diminishing visual field. She was found to have a pituitary mass and underwent trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy. Now she has low levels of ACTH, TSH, FSH, and LH. Which of the following hormone supplements is not needed in the patient postoperatively? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mineralocorticoids

 

After a trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy, the pituitary gland's ability to produce several hormones including ACTH, TSH, FSH, and LH can be impaired. The lack of ACTH typically necessitates glucocorticoid replacement, but not mineralocorticoid supplementation. This is because the regulation of mineralocorticoids (primarily aldosterone) is mainly via the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), which operates independently of the pituitary gland. Aldosterone secretion is primarily controlled by plasma potassium levels and the RAAS, not ACTH, although ACTH can have a stimulatory effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucocorticoids: Low dose steroid supplementation is required as they are ACTH dependent.

 

Option C. Thyroid hormones: Necessary due to diminished TSH, which is essential for thyroid hormone synthesis and secretion. LT4 supplementation targeting T4 levels is required.

 

Option D. Estradiol: While gonadotropin supplementation post-pituitary surgery can be complex, replacement might be necessary due to the absence of FSH and LH, affecting estrogen levels.

 

Educational Objective:


Post-hypophysectomy, patients often require supplementation of several hormones, including glucocorticoids and thyroid hormones, due to impaired pituitary function. However, mineralocorticoid supplementation is typically not needed as aldosterone secretion is primarily regulated by the RAAS system, independent of pituitary control.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/ Chapter 379/

questions.text: What is the most prevalent type of intracranial hemorrhage? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intracerebral hemorrhage

 

Explanation:

 

Intracerebral hemorrhage, occurring within the brain parenchyma, is the most common form of intracranial hemorrhage. This type typically results from the rupture of small perforating arteries or arterioles weakened primarily by chronic hypertension, leading to bleeding directly into the brain tissue. This can occur in areas such as the basal ganglia, thalamus, pons, or cerebellum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage: Incorrect. While serious, subarachnoid hemorrhages are less common and typically result from the rupture of aneurysms rather than hypertension.
 

Option C. Subdural Hemorrhage: Incorrect. Subdural hemorrhages, usually due to venous tears, are more commonly associated with trauma rather than spontaneous vascular events.
 

Option D. Extradural Hemorrhage: Incorrect. Extradural (epidural) hemorrhages are rare and almost exclusively trauma-related, involving bleeding between the inner surface of the skull and the dura mater.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary cause of intracerebral hemorrhage is hypertension, which leads to the rupture of small arteries in the brain, emphasizing the importance of managing blood pressure to prevent such critical events.

questions.text: A 25-year-old software engineer presented with fatigue and lethargy. He worked for 12-14 hours a day, and his diet pattern consisted predominantly of fast food with very little veggies and greens. Labs: Hb - 9, MCV 106. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Folate deficiency

 

The patient presents with macrocytic anemia, indicated by an MCV of 106. Macrocytic anemia is often caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate. The patient's dietary habits, which include a diet predominantly of fast food with very little vegetables and greens, suggest a lack of dietary folate.

 

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency: Typically occurs in individuals who do not consume animal products (vegans). This deficiency is less likely in this patient due to the absence of such a dietary restriction.
  • Folate deficiency: Common in individuals with poor intake of vegetables and greens. This matches the patient's dietary pattern.
  • Iron deficiency: Results in microcytic anemia (MCV < 80), not macrocytic anemia.
  • Hemolytic anemia: Usually presents as normocytic anemia (MCV 80-100) with increased reticulocyte count and elevated LDH, which does not match the lab findings of this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B12 deficiency: While B12 deficiency causes macrocytic anemia, it is more common in individuals who avoid animal products. The patient's history does not indicate a dietary restriction on animal products.

 

Option C. Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency causes microcytic anemia (low MCV), which is not consistent with the patient's lab findings of an MCV of 106.

 

Option D. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia typically presents with normocytic anemia and increased reticulocyte count, not with the high MCV seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folate deficiency should be considered in patients with macrocytic anemia and poor dietary intake of vegetables and greens. This deficiency can cause fatigue and lethargy and is confirmed by a high MCV and dietary history.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with weakness, fatigue, and pallor. Lab reports show low Hb, very low reticulocyte count, and macrocytosis. Neurological examination reveals decreased vibration and position sense in lower limbs. What is the likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pernicious anemia

 

The combination of macrocytic anemia, low reticulocyte count, and neurological symptoms (posterior column signs) strongly suggests vitamin B12 deficiency leading to pernicious anemia. The low reticulocyte count indicates ineffective erythropoiesis, which is characteristic of megaloblastic anemias. The neurological manifestations occur due to demyelination of the posterior and lateral columns of the spinal cord (subacute combined degeneration).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia of chronic disease: While this can present with low reticulocyte count, it typically causes normocytic or mildly microcytic anemia and doesn't cause neurological manifestations.

 

Option B. Aplastic crisis: This would typically affect all cell lines causing pancytopenia, and doesn't cause macrocytosis or neurological symptoms.

 

Option C. Hemolytic anemia: This condition is characterized by high reticulocyte count due to compensatory increased production of RBCs, which is opposite to the findings in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pernicious anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency presents with macrocytic anemia, low reticulocyte count (indicating ineffective erythropoiesis), and neurological manifestations due to posterior column involvement. The presence of neurological symptoms helps distinguish it from other causes of macrocytic anemia.
